{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3554316,"name":"Wihy","username":"Wihy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wihy/{size}/225659_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T18:23:45.581Z","cooked":"

So we had both of our competitions, and during both of these dumb mistakes plagued are code. Sometimes one line of code ruined an entire day of the event.

Ill give some examples:
Our characterization gave us a negative wheel radius, which wasnt double checked - causing problems with odometery.

Pathplanner was only using the odometry pose, so it didnt know its initial pose.

LED commands (which were added at the event) never stopped, causing the auto to not execute

My question is as follows: What are some best practices your team follows to ensure the code is absolutely bulletproof? In general, but especially when writing code in comp

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T18:23:45.581Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":60,"reads":580,"readers_count":579,"score":496.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Wihy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61960,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Driver & Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554320,"name":"Caleb Ryon","username":"CalebRyon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calebryon/{size}/255718_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T18:26:34.570Z","cooked":"

Don’t add new code during qualifying and playoffs matches. Tune auto pid ect. Fix numbers. If you really need to code test it on the practice field before your match if possible.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T18:26:34.570Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":566,"readers_count":565,"score":358.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Caleb Ryon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":16}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71153,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"967 Drive Coach + Lead Programmer "},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":16}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":16,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554322,"name":"Bill","username":"LiarMcLiarPants","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/liarmcliarpants/{size}/247645_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T18:27:08.549Z","cooked":"

My team has found that the best way to avoid errors in code in the past is to create a fork of the code before every change, to make sure code is triple checked on that fork before syncing it back to main. We never change a piece of code and push it directly to main, even at comp, or even for the smallest change, just in case.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T18:27:08.549Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":543,"readers_count":542,"score":188.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Bill","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71990,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554325,"name":"Drakxii","username":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T18:29:19.637Z","cooked":"

Reviewers, standards and variables that explain what they are for instead of “LFSDMN5”.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T18:30:54.167Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":506,"readers_count":505,"score":101.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Drakxii","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23134,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI "},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554329,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T18:31:51.230Z","cooked":"
Wihy:

Our characterization gave us a negative wheel radius, which wasnt double checked - causing problems with odometery.

One way to avoid problems like this is to make sure your team members are not relying on tooling that they do not understand well enough to troubleshoot or validate.

Build a team culture where it is unacceptable to “just copy the values,” and you’ll see fewer problems from blindly copying values.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T18:31:51.230Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":482,"readers_count":481,"score":471.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":23}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":16},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":23,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555150,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T16:17:53.037Z","cooked":"

Unit tests and sim tests are about all you’ve got when creating code during an event. Even then it’s not going to be fool proof.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T16:17:53.037Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":372,"readers_count":371,"score":89.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Justin Buist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24678,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555159,"name":"","username":"person4268","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T16:23:09.428Z","cooked":"
  • Having functioning sim so you can test most kinds of changes on some level. It goes a long way to having code work first try.
  • Never copying something without fully understand how, and why it works (constants, gear ratio calculations, inversions, too)
  • Testing things and making sure they’re working as expected, and that intermediate numbers make sense to you (thorough logging helps with this)
  • Avoiding writing code at comps period, unless you thoroughly understand the implications of what your changing and have time to test it on the practice field. A lot of your issues really do stem from changing things on the field without any testing. If you don’t have time to test, even lightly, you shouldn’t run it (an exception might be minor nudges to auto paths).
  • When testing, trying out all possible situations you can think of (different alliances, whether your teleop code works fine after auton or mid-match code restart, etc)
","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T16:23:09.428Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":368,"readers_count":367,"score":138.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55016,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555203,"name":"Andrew Todd","username":"Andrew123ast","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew123ast/{size}/243883_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T16:41:46.166Z","cooked":"

Use Git!

We always have our main branch be competition ready code. Any changes are made on feature branches, then merged into main. Main should always work 100%.

Force your build team to dedicate time to testing code if they aren’t already. I know everyone wants to be working on things, but code MUST be tested.

Use a simulator if possible. This year, we started using Advantage Kit, Advantage Scope, and Maple Sim and it has been a huge help.

In terms of writing the code, having some sort of linter set up would help. Peer review code before it gets deployed. Lots of reading of docs and code from other teams. You can also utilize copilot to help review your code. I would not trust it to generate code wholesale though. Having a document of best practices, or a style guide you follow might also help.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T16:41:46.166Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":331,"readers_count":330,"score":101.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Andrew Todd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71098,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alumni | Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555216,"name":"","username":"Hollisms","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hollisms/{size}/110925_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T16:49:50.093Z","cooked":"

Use the simulator.
Use the debugger. Set breakpoints on new code and step through it.
Use the units library.

Be very careful. If you have to make a change at a competition & you can’t get to the test field get the robot up on blocks and test it. (Run your auto on blocks to make sure it does its thing.) Note: Be very careful.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T16:49:50.093Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":65.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36169,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555222,"name":"Kyle Reeve","username":"kreeve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kreeve/{size}/187015_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T16:53:27.075Z","cooked":"

Using replay with Advantage kit won’t necessarily prevent stupid mistakes, but it allows you to quickly validate fixes on a short timeline. We had a practice match last weekend where the robot was always aligning to the wrong face on the red side (our practice field just has blue tags). After finding out what the issue was before our next practice, we were able to prove via replay that the issue had been fixed. Red is robot pose, green is where it tried to align during match, magenta is where it would have tried to align during replay.

image-15999×955 199 KB

Even in “the industry”, code reviews and tests can’t catch everything, and what’s more important is being set up to make and validate fixes quickly.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T16:57:56.060Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":296,"readers_count":295,"score":109.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Kyle Reeve","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.advantagekit.org/getting-started/traditional-replay","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"How To: Traditional Replay | AdvantageKit","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10385,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555232,"name":"","username":"Wesley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wesley/{size}/155134_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T17:06:26.118Z","cooked":"

While at the event, tag commits with the match number they played in— so if commit X was running on the robot during quals Y, tag it with QM#Y or similar.

This doesn’t exactly help prevent problems, but it does let you pair code to match video. This is especially relevant if you’re making a lot of minor tuning tweaks at comp.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T17:06:26.118Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":83.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48578,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"95's programming team from 2021 to 2024"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555233,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T17:07:56.733Z","cooked":"

All good advice here but really…

Wihy:

especially when writing code in comp

Just don’t.

Every line of code changed is a risk of introducing a new bug.

Structure your build season in a way that makes sure software is written and validated prior to getting to competition. Then keep your efforts on robustness, not adding new features mid competition (which, all three of your bugs looked related to).

If that’s not possible - yes, the rest of the advice here can help mitigate the risk of change code mid-comp. But it doesn’t change the fact that every line of code changed is a risk for another bug introduced.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T17:07:56.733Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":261,"readers_count":260,"score":117.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/12","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555236,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T17:10:54.488Z","cooked":"

(1) New fork for every change
(2) Test the change on the practice field
(3) Have somebody else inspect the code change. Programmers are universally blind to their own dumb errors, but do a good job of picking up somebody else’s.

Making code changes that you don’t thoroughly test and then putting them into your production robot is a high-risk activity. There is no way to make that “bulletproof,” only ways to marginally reduce the risk.

[I’m a huge fan of code reviews done at an early stage. They can dramatically shorten the amount of time it takes to test and debug code. Unfortunately, a lot of people do the testing and debugging, and THEN do a code review.]

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T17:14:44.595Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":249,"readers_count":248,"score":64.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/13","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555244,"name":"DylanB","username":"DylanB","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/aeb1de/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T17:17:04.413Z","cooked":"

Echoing a lot of things gerth said above. At a fundamental level, these aren’t software problems, they’re process and project management problems. The problems. you’re facing are ones you should have figured out at the shop or on the practice field weeks before competition.

All the other advice mentioned above is awesome, do that too! But all of those are just addressing the symptoms, not the root cause. Your team needs to figure out how to prevent this from happening again next year. And 9/10 times, the solution is building a simpler, more consistent, more robust robot. That’s often a robot that does less things, but that’s okay. 118 took an Everybot to elims match 13 as an alliance captain. Simple robots operating at incredibly high levels of consistency with high level software will take your team very far.

I know, skill issue.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T17:29:53.018Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":220,"readers_count":219,"score":64.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Andrew Todd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71098,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alumni | Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/15","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555267,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T17:36:33.502Z","cooked":"

I can count on zero fingers the number of people I’ve met in 10+ years as a pro software developer who can write bug-free software in limited time.

Not a skill issue, just a misalignment in risk acceptance.

If the team’s ok with losing a few matches due to software bugs, yolo and deploy to your heart’s content!

If the team doesn’t want that risk, you gotta project plan up front to develop things a bit more.

Your mechanical team wouldn’t accept bolting on a brand new mechanism while physically on the field - you’d put it on in the pit first, and check it works before putting it out there. No reason your software team should accept putting untested code to field either.

In my experience, the real gap is usually in describing the risk and the risk mitigation to non-software people. Lost matches are often a great starting point for the discussion, though.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T17:37:38.508Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":228,"readers_count":227,"score":180.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495185,"topic_slug":"how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":71098,"username":"Andrew123ast","name":"Andrew Todd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew123ast/{size}/243883_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-avoid-stupid-mistakes-in-code/495185/16","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555384,"name":"Justin Nesselrotte","username":"jnesselr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnesselr/{size}/199903_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T19:27:05.134Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

I can count on zero fingers the number of people I’ve met in 10+ years as a pro software developer who can write bug-free software in limited time.

Not a skill issue, just a misalignment in risk acceptance.

Absolutely this. Last year, my team essentially ran into a roadblock where the code was complicated enough in one section that they couldn’t fix a bug that was found in production. I made the judgement call to refactor the code on the fly (with students sitting there so I could explain/walk through the process and I forced them to review the PR later), and I mostly succeeded in that effort. But I’ll never forget that we essentially were down one match because of a behavior change. It wasn’t something that changed in the process of refactoring, it was entirely an “oh by the way can you make it do X”. And while that worked, it required our drive team to set up the robot in a specific way. I messed up the explanation and boom, down a match.

With that being said, here’s my recommendations:

  • Don’t edit code during a competition. Ever. (Some exceptions apply)
  • Do what you can in advance to reduce risk. There’s a laundry list of things to do and many of them have been mentioned, but I’ll list some of my favorite ones below.
  • A competition is a high pressure situation. The easiest way to make a mistake is to get tunnel vision. As a programmer, ESPECIALLY if you haven’t actually had any “Production is down, and this is costing $$$$ / second of down time” issues in the “real world”, you probably don’t even know how you’ll react, much less how to make good decisions in that moment.
  • NEVER only have one programmer (if you can help it). Whenever I’ve done pit scouting, the first thing I look for is if your robot is on fire. Usually that’s not the case, so I move on to the second thing which is “do you have more than one programmer”. It’s pretty easy to spot, I ask “who’s your programmer” and when I get pointed to one person who looks super stressed staring at a laptop, that’s the single point of failure. Everyone else on your team looks at what you do as voodoo. You might enjoy that feeling, but the failure mode is that no one can help you and no one understands the risk of you changing things. Depending on team culture, if you mess up the code, you might be blamed by others for the team losing.
  • Read your documentation. I get it, it’s boring. The number of times where I just went “oh yeah, use this class with these parameters” not because I memorized it, but because I skimmed it and know where to look? Really high. Skim the class tree, look at interesting classes. Options to set configuration values and control schemes are my two biggest things to look out for.
  • Be customer obsessed. The drive team is your customer. What do they need? Ensure there’s a dialog between what you’re able to do as a programmer and what your driver wants. Offer suggestions. “Oh, you have to press X to move this, and Y to stop? Would just holding X work better?” Unless your driver is a programmer (highly recommend, having had that the last 2 seasons), they won’t know what you can do.
  • Understand that there are no stupid mistakes. You may slap your forehead and go “d’oh” when you realize the mistake, but that doesn’t make it a stupid mistake. There was a reason you made the mistake. As you grow as an engineer, you learn not only how to spot mistakes quickly, but also how to write code in such a way as to avoid mistakes. You making mistakes is not because you’re a failure. It’s because you’re learning. I made plenty of dumb mistakes, but I can tell you the first one I remember is pushing code that caused 150 3d printers to stop dead. Full production halt. Silly mistake, big cost. That one mistake taught me more lessons in 5 minutes than several years of school did. Self loathing was not one of the mistakes.

That block of text down, let me make another one! These are common “code smells” I see in the FRC world / advice on how to mitigate them.

  • Use the command/subsystem methodology. For the most part, I don’t have to teach students about pseudo real-time systems this way. But it also helps keep things concise.
  • Make your commands composable. If you have one command that intakes, passes it up to the shooter, then shoots, you have too many commands in your command.
  • Some commands should not be broken up. If you have a StartIntake command and a StopIntake command, just make a RunIntake command. Your start code goes in initialize, your stop goes in end. Instead of onTrue to run the start command and onFalse to run the stop, just do whileTrue. Your command will be scheduled when you press the button and cancelled when you let go of the button. Bonus, you can use isFinished in the command to listen for sensors and automatically cancel the command as needed.
  • Avoid toggles like the plague, especially dual state toggles. If you have something with 2 states, and you’re thinking “I’ll use a boolean value to represent it”, DON’T. There’s several problems with this. The first is that you’re begging the universe to give you a third state. The second is that almost always, you have a “toggle” method that relies on the consumer knowing what the current state is and what the state they want to be at is. If your consumer assumes the state or is wrong due to race conditions or whatever, you end up with a dual toggle. Your arm needs your intake to be up to grab it, but due to some other issue in code, the arm thinks the intake is down when it’s up and it toggles it. Boom, it actually goes down and you can’t grab the piece. Be explicit and use enums to fix all of these issues.
  • Speaking of which, use enums liberally. Robots are very stateful. Enums encode state. Healthy bonus, in Java you can use constructors in an enum. So I’ll encode setpoints, slot configs, etc. all inside an enum state. You can pass that enum around and set things up as necessary to achieve that state.
  • Avoid making new commands when you want to execute them. Make them as fields somewhere on a class, ideally one you can self-reference (ie to schedule one command as soon as another ends). This is mostly to help with understanding the why behind a command. For example, you shouldn’t name your RunIntake command runIntake. Name it something like pullInCoral or rejectCoralFromIntake. Java gives you 65,535 characters to name a variable. Feel free to use a few extra. Whenever I see controller.x().onTrue(new StartIntake(intakeSubsystem, 1)), I have to go figure out what that 1 means in context to help verify correctness. If it’s controller.x().whileTrue(pullInCoral), then that’s much more descriptive.
  • State is your enemy. As I said, robots are stateful. Never trust your state. Mark fields that should not change as final so they can only be made in the constructor. Avoid interlocking fields, meaning if two fields have to change at the same time, you should probably encode those fields together in either an enum (if there’s a limited set of options) or another class that only exposes methods to transform those in a sane way. You can probably unit test that class to verify correctness. Inner classes that can access fields from your outer class are your friend here. Lastly, re-deploying is the same as wiping the slate clean. Disable your robot and then re-enable it without restarting code to find state bugs. Timers not resetting properly is a big one I’ve found.
  • A contract for each class must be thought about both in how that class is used and how that class protects its integrity. If you have a subsystem that allows someone to directly control a motor, you’re probably exposing too much. The public methods you expose are an agreement as to how your system should be used. If you have an intake with a left/right motor, don’t make a “set left” and “set right” speed IF part of the contract is that the motors must always be moving at the same speed with different direction. Just make one “set speed” command that moves both motors. Also beware of if that contract changes, ie you find one motor needs to move faster than the other, and what the effects on your contract will be.
  • Develop contracts with your programming team on how things should work. If you have two motors as before, if you can, avoid making one be a positive speed and the other be the negative speed. Instead, the team contract should be “all motors intaking should be positive to intake, negative to eject”. Similar ones are “Arms should move positive counterclockwise” and “elevators should move positive up”. Configure your motors to work that way and coding will be easier.

That’s all for now! Sorry for the blocks of text, but programming and helping people avoid mistakes is something I’m passionate about both for FRC and the real world!
